introduction.title: C# Introduction
paragraphs: What is C#?
C# is pronounced "C-Sharp".
It is an object-oriented programming language created by Microsoft that runs on the .NET Framework.
C# has roots from the C family, and the language is close to other popular languages like C++ and Java.
The first version was released in year 2002.
The latest version, C# 13, was released in November 2024.

sections.name: uses
sections.heading: C# is used for:
list: Mobile applications
Desktop applications
Web applications
Web services
Web sites
Games
VR
Database applications
And much, much more!

sections.name: why-use
sections.heading: Why Use C#?
list: It is one of the most popular programming languages in the world
It is easy to learn and simple to use
It has huge community support
C# is an object-oriented language which gives a clear structure to programs and allows code to be reused, lowering development costs
As C# is close to C, C++ and Java, it makes it easy for programmers to switch to C# or vice versa

sections.name: get-started
sections.heading: Get Started
paragraphs: This tutorial will teach you the basics of C#.
It is not necessary to have any prior programming experience.

The easiest way to get started with C# is to use an IDE.
An IDE (Integrated Development Environment) is used to edit and compile code.

sections.name: ide
sections.heading: C# IDE
paragraphs: In our tutorial, we will use Visual Studio Community, which is free to download from https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/vs/community/.
Applications written in C# use the .NET Framework, so it makes sense to use Visual Studio, as the program, the framework, and the language, are all created by Microsoft.

sections.name: install
sections.heading: C# Install
paragraphs: Once the Visual Studio Installer is downloaded and installed, choose the .NET workload and click on the Modify/Install button.
After the installation is complete, click on the Launch button to get started with Visual Studio.

sections.name: create-project
sections.heading: Create a New Project
paragraphs: On the start window, choose Create a new project.
Then click on the "Install more tools and features" link.
Choose "Console App (.NET Core)" from the list and click on the Next button.
Enter a name for your project, and click on the Create button.
Visual Studio will automatically generate some code for your project.

sections.name: example

sections.name: explained
sections.heading: Example explained
paragraphs: Line 1: using System means that we can use classes from the System namespace.
Line 2: A blank line. C# ignores white space. However, multiple lines makes the code more readable.
Line 3: namespace is used to organize your code, and it is a container for classes and other namespaces.
Line 4: The curly braces {} marks the beginning and the end of a block of code.
Line 5: class is a container for data and methods, which brings functionality to your program. Every line of code that runs in C# must be inside a class. In our example, we named the class Program.

Don't worry if you don't understand how using System, namespace and class works. Just think of it as something that (almost) always appears in your program, and that you will learn more about them in a later chapter.

Line 7: Another thing that always appear in a C# program is the Main method. Any code inside its curly brackets {} will be executed. You don't have to understand the keywords before and after Main. You will get to know them bit by bit while reading this tutorial.
Line 9: Console is a class of the System namespace, which has a WriteLine() method that is used to output/print text. In our example, it will output "Hello World!".
If you omit the using System line, you would have to write System.Console.WriteLine() to print/output text.

comments.title: C# Comments
paragraphs: C# Comments
Comments can be used to explain C# code, and to make it more readable.
It can also be used to prevent execution when testing alternative code.

sections.name: single-line
sections.heading: Single-line Comments
paragraphs: Single-line comments start with two forward slashes (//).
Any text between // and the end of the line is ignored by C# (will not be executed).
This example uses a single-line comment before a line of code:
sections.example:
// This is a comment
Console.WriteLine("Hello World!");

sections.name: single-line-end
sections.heading: Single-line Comment at the End of a Line
paragraphs: This example uses a single-line comment at the end of a line of code:
sections.example: Console.WriteLine("Hello World!");  // This is a comment

sections.name: multi-line
sections.heading: C# Multi-line Comments
paragraphs: Multi-line comments start with /* and ends with */.
Any text between /* and */ will be ignored by C#.
This example uses a multi-line comment (a comment block) to explain the code:

sections.name: single-vs-multi
sections.heading: Single or multi-line comments?
paragraphs: It is up to you which you want to use.
Normally, we use // for short comments, and /* */ for longer.

variables.title: C# Variables

Variables are containers for storing data values.
In C#, there are different types of variables (defined with different keywords).

double - stores floating point numbers, with decimals, such as 19.99 or -19.99
char - stores single characters, such as 'a' or 'B'. Char values are surrounded by single quotes
string - stores text, such as "Hello World". String values are surrounded by double quotes
bool - stores values with two states: true or false

data-types.title: C# Data Types
paragraphs: C# Data Types
As explained in the variables chapter, a variable in C# must be a specified data type.

sections.name: example
sections.heading: Example
sections.example:
int myNum = 5;               // Integer (whole number)
double myDoubleNum = 5.99D;  // Floating point number
char myLetter = 'D';         // Character
bool myBool = true;          // Boolean
string myText = "Hello";     // String

sections.name: about
sections.heading: What is a Data Type?
paragraphs: A data type specifies the size and type of variable values.
It is important to use the correct data type for the corresponding variable; to avoid errors, to save time and memory, but it will also make your code more maintainable and readable.

rows: Stores fractional numbers. Sufficient for storing 6 to 7 decimal digits
Stores fractional numbers. Sufficient for storing 15 decimal digits
Stores a single character/letter, surrounded by single quotes
Stores a sequence of characters, surrounded by double quotes

sections.name: numbers
sections.heading: Numbers
paragraphs: Number types are divided into two groups:
Integer types stores whole numbers, positive or negative (such as 123 or -456), without decimals. Valid types are int and long.
Floating point types represents numbers with a fractional part, containing one or more decimals. Valid types are float and double.
The most used for numbers are int (for whole numbers) and double (for floating point numbers).

sections.name: int
sections.heading: Int
paragraphs: The int data type can store whole numbers from -2147483648 to 2147483647.
In general, the int data type is the preferred data type when we create variables with a numeric value.
sections.example:
int myNum = 100000;
Console.WriteLine(myNum);

sections.name: long
sections.heading: Long
paragraphs: The long data type can store whole numbers from -9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807.
This is used when int is not large enough to store the value.
You should end the value with an "L".
sections.example:
long myNum = 15000000000L;
Console.WriteLine(myNum);

sections.name: floating-point
sections.heading: Floating Point Types
paragraphs: You should use a floating point type whenever you need a number with a decimal, such as 9.99 or 3.14515.
The float and double data types can store fractional numbers.
End the value with an "F" for floats and "D" for doubles.

sections.name: float-vs-double
sections.heading: Use float or double?
paragraphs: The precision of a floating point value indicates how many digits the value can have after the decimal point.
The precision of float is only six or seven decimal digits, while double variables have a precision of about 15 digits.
Therefore it is safer to use double for most calculations.

sections.name: scientific
sections.heading: Scientific Numbers
paragraphs: A floating point number can also be a scientific number with an "e" to indicate the power of 10:

sections.note: Boolean values are mostly used for conditional testing.

sections.name: characters
sections.heading: Characters
paragraphs: The char data type is used to store a single character.
The character must be surrounded by single quotes, like 'A' or 'c':
sections.example:

sections.name: strings
sections.heading: Strings
paragraphs: The string data type is used to store a sequence of characters (text).
String values must be surrounded by double quotes:

type-casting.title: C# Type Casting
paragraphs: C# Type Casting
Type casting is when you assign a value of one data type to another type.
In C#, there are two types of casting:

sections.name: types
sections.heading: Types of Casting
list: Implicit Casting (automatically) - converting a smaller type to a larger type size
char -> int -> long -> float -> double
Explicit Casting (manually) - converting a larger type to a smaller size type
double -> float -> long -> int -> char

sections.name: implicit
sections.heading: Implicit Casting
paragraphs: Implicit casting is done automatically when passing a smaller size type to a larger size type:
sections.example:
int myInt = 9;
double myDouble = myInt;       // Automatic casting: int to double

Console.WriteLine(myInt);      // Outputs 9
Console.WriteLine(myDouble);   // Outputs 9

sections.name: explicit
sections.heading: Explicit Casting
paragraphs: Explicit casting must be done manually by placing the type in parentheses in front of the value:
sections.example:
double myDouble = 9.78;
int myInt = (int) myDouble;    // Manual casting: double to int

Console.WriteLine(myDouble);   // Outputs 9.78
Console.WriteLine(myInt);      // Outputs 9

sections.name: conversion-methods
sections.heading: Type Conversion Methods
paragraphs: It is also possible to convert data types explicitly by using built-in methods, such as Convert.ToBoolean, Convert.ToDouble, Convert.ToString, Convert.ToInt32 (int) and Convert.ToInt64 (long):

sections.name: why
sections.heading: Why Conversion?

But sometimes you have to.
Take a look at the next chapter, when working with user input, to see an example of this.

exercise.question: What is implicit casting in C#?

Automatically converting a smaller type to a larger type size.
exercise.answer: Automatically converting a smaller type to a larger type size.

The C# Math class has many methods that allows you to perform mathematical tasks on numbers.

booleans.title: C# Booleans
paragraphs: C# Booleans
Very often, in programming, you will need a data type that can only have one of two values, like:

ON / OFF

For this, C# has a bool data type, which can take the values true or false.

sections.heading: Boolean Values

sections.name: boolean-expression
sections.heading: Boolean Expression

This is useful to build logic, and find answers.
examples: Console.WriteLine(10 > 9); // returns True, because 10 is higher than 9

int x = 10;
Console.WriteLine(x == 10); // returns True, because the value of x is equal to 10
Console.WriteLine(10 == 15); // returns False, because 10 is not equal to 15

A break can save a lot of execution time because it ignores the execution of all the rest of the code in the switch block.

Loops are handy because they save time, reduce errors, and they make code more readable.

methods.title: C# Methods
paragraphs: A method is a block of code which only runs when it is called.
You can pass data, known as parameters, into a method.
Methods are used to perform certain actions, and they are also known as functions.
Why use methods? To reuse code: define the code once, and use it many times.

sections.name: create-method
sections.heading: Create a Method
paragraphs: A method is defined with the name of the method, followed by parentheses ().
C# provides some pre-defined methods, such as Main(), but you can also create your own methods.

sections.name: example-explained
sections.heading: Example Explained
points: MyMethod() is the name of the method
static means that the method belongs to the Program class and not an object of the Program class
void means that this method does not have a return value
sections.note: In C#, it is good practice to start with an uppercase letter when naming methods.

sections.name: call-method
sections.heading: Call a Method
paragraphs: To call (execute) a method, write the method's name followed by two parentheses () and a semicolon ;

sections.name: parameters-and-arguments
sections.heading: Parameters and Arguments
paragraphs: Information can be passed to methods as parameter. Parameters act as variables inside the method.
They are specified after the method name, inside the parentheses.
You can add as many parameters as you want, just separate them with a comma.

sections.name: parameter-vs-argument
sections.heading: Parameter vs Argument
paragraphs: When a parameter is passed to the method, it is called an argument.
From the example above: fname is a parameter, while Liam, Jenny and Anja are arguments.

sections.name: multiple-parameters
sections.heading: Multiple Parameters
paragraphs: You can have as many parameters as you like, just separate them with commas.

sections.name: note
sections.heading: Note
sections.note: When working with multiple parameters, the method call must have the same number of arguments as there are parameters, and the arguments must be passed in the same order.

sections.heading: Method Overloading
paragraphs: With method overloading, multiple methods can have the same name with different parameters.
sections.example:
int MyMethod(int x)
float MyMethod(float x)
double MyMethod(double x, double y)

sections.heading: Note
sections.note: Multiple methods can have the same name as long as the number and/or type of parameters are different.

sections.name: what-is-oop
sections.heading: C# - What is OOP?
paragraphs: OOP stands for Object-Oriented Programming.
Procedural programming is about writing procedures or methods that perform operations on the data, while object-oriented programming is about creating objects that contain both data and methods.
Object-oriented programming has several advantages over procedural programming:
list: OOP is faster and easier to execute
OOP provides a clear structure for the programs
OOP helps to keep the C# code DRY "Don't Repeat Yourself", and makes the code easier to maintain, modify and debug
OOP makes it possible to create full reusable applications with less code and shorter development time

sections.name: tip-dry
sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: The "Don't Repeat Yourself" (DRY) principle is about reducing the repetition of code. You should extract out the codes that are common for the application, and place them at a single place and reuse them instead of repeating it.

sections.name: classes-and-objects
sections.heading: C# - What are Classes and Objects?
paragraphs: Classes and objects are the two main aspects of object-oriented programming.
A class is a template for objects, and an object is an instance of a class.
When the individual objects are created, they inherit all the variables and methods from the class.
You will learn much more about classes and objects in the next chapter.

exercise.question: What does OOP stand for?

sections.name: classes-and-objects
sections.heading: Classes and Objects
paragraphs: You learned from the previous chapter that C# is an object-oriented programming language.
Everything in C# is associated with classes and objects, along with its attributes and methods.
For example: in real life, a car is an object. The car has attributes, such as weight and color, and methods, such as drive and brake.
A Class is like an object constructor, or a "blueprint" for creating objects.

sections.name: create-a-class
sections.heading: Create a Class
paragraphs: To create a class, use the class keyword:
Create a class named "Car" with a variable color:

sections.name: field-note
sections.heading: Note
paragraphs: When a variable is declared directly in a class, it is often referred to as a field (or attribute).
It is not required, but it is a good practice to start with an uppercase first letter when naming classes.
It is common that the name of the C# file and the class matches, as it makes our code organized.
However it is not required (like in Java).

sections.name: create-an-object
sections.heading: Create an Object
paragraphs: An object is created from a class.
We have already created the class named Car, so now we can use this to create objects.
To create an object of Car, specify the class name, followed by the object name, and use the keyword new:
Create an object called "myObj" and use it to print the value of color:

sections.name: dot-syntax
sections.heading: Note
paragraphs: We use the dot syntax (.) to access variables/fields inside a class (myObj.color).
You will learn more about fields in the next chapter.

exercise.question: Drag and drop the correct keyword to define the class.

sections.name: class-members
sections.heading: Class Members
paragraphs: Fields and methods inside classes are often referred to as "Class Members".

sections.name: fields
sections.heading: Fields
paragraphs: Variables inside a class are called fields.
You can access them by creating an object of the class, and by using the dot syntax (.).
The following example creates an object of the Car class and prints the values of the fields color and maxSpeed:

sections.name: modify-fields-after-creating-object
sections.heading: Modify Fields After Creating Object
paragraphs: You can also leave the fields blank, and modify them when creating the object:

sections.name: multiple-objects
sections.heading: Multiple Objects
paragraphs: This is especially useful when creating multiple objects of one class:

sections.name: object-methods
sections.heading: Object Methods
paragraphs: Methods are used to perform certain actions.
Methods normally belong to a class, and they define how an object of a class behaves.
You can access methods with the dot syntax.
The method must be public.
Use the name of the method followed by parentheses () and a semicolon ; to call the method:

sections.name: public-vs-static
sections.heading: Public vs Static
paragraphs: A static method can be accessed without creating an object of the class.
Public methods can only be accessed by objects.

sections.name: use-multiple-classes
sections.heading: Use Multiple Classes
paragraphs: You can use multiple classes for better organization (one for fields and methods, and another one for execution).
This is recommended:

sections.name: access-modifier-note
sections.heading: Note
paragraphs: The public keyword is called an access modifier.
It specifies that the fields of Car are accessible for other classes as well, such as Program.
You will learn more about Access Modifiers in a later chapter.

sections.name: tip
sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: As you continue to read, you will also learn more about other class members, such as constructors and properties.

exercise.question: What are class members in C#?
options: Only the fields (variables) inside a class.
Only the methods inside a class.
Both fields (variables) and methods inside a class.
Only the constructors of a class.
exercise.answer: Both fields (variables) and methods inside a class.

sections.name: constructors
sections.heading: Constructors
paragraphs: A constructor is a special method that is used to initialize objects.
The advantage of a constructor is that it is called when an object of a class is created.
It can be used to set initial values for fields.

sections.name: constructor-rules
sections.heading: Constructor Rules
paragraphs: The constructor name must match the class name.
A constructor cannot have a return type (like void or int).
The constructor is called when the object is created.
All classes have constructors by default. If you do not create a class constructor yourself, C# creates one for you.
Without your own constructor, you cannot set initial values for fields.

sections.name: constructor-parameters
sections.heading: Constructor Parameters
paragraphs: Constructors can also take parameters, which is used to initialize fields.
In this example, we add a string modelName parameter to the constructor.
Inside the constructor we set model to modelName (model=modelName).

sections.name: multiple-parameters
sections.heading: Multiple Parameters
paragraphs: You can have as many parameters as you want.

sections.name: constructor-overloading
sections.heading: Tip
sections.tip: Just like other methods, constructors can be overloaded by using different numbers of parameters.

sections.name: constructors-save-time
sections.heading: Constructors Save Time
paragraphs: Constructors are very useful because they help reduce the amount of code.

exercise.question: What is a constructor in C#?
options: A method used to destroy objects.
A method that must return a value.
A method that can only be called manually.
A method used to initialize objects when they are created.
exercise.answer: A method used to initialize objects when they are created.

sections.name: access-modifiers
sections.heading: Access Modifiers
paragraphs: The public keyword is an access modifier.
Access modifiers are used to set the access level/visibility for classes, fields, methods and properties.
sections.example: public string color;

sections.name: types-of-access-modifiers
sections.heading: C# has the following access modifiers

modifiers.name: public
modifiers.description: The code is accessible for all classes

modifiers.name: private
modifiers.description: The code is only accessible within the same class

modifiers.name: protected
modifiers.description: The code is accessible within the same class, or in a class that is inherited from that class

modifiers.name: internal
modifiers.description: The code is only accessible within its own assembly, but not from another assembly

sections.note: There are also two combinations: protected internal and private protected.

sections.name: private-modifier
sections.heading: Private Modifier
paragraphs: If you declare a field with a private access modifier, it can only be accessed within the same class.

sections.name: private-outside-error
sections.heading: Accessing private field outside class
paragraphs: If you try to access a private field outside the class, an error will occur.

sections.name: public-modifier
sections.heading: Public Modifier
paragraphs: If you declare a field with a public access modifier, it is accessible for all classes.

sections.name: why-access-modifiers
sections.heading: Why Access Modifiers?
points: To control the visibility of class members (security level).
To achieve Encapsulation (hide sensitive data) by declaring fields as private.

sections.name: default-private
sections.heading: Default Access Modifier
paragraphs: By default, all members of a class are private if you don't specify an access modifier.

exercise.question: What is the purpose of access modifiers in C#?
options: To determine how objects are created.
To set the visibility and accessibility of classes, fields, and methods.
To specify the return type of a method.
To control the execution order of methods.
exercise.answer: To set the visibility and accessibility of classes, fields, and methods.

sections.name: properties-and-encapsulation
sections.heading: Properties and Encapsulation
paragraphs: Encapsulation means making sure that sensitive data is hidden from users.
To achieve encapsulation in C#, you must:
1) declare fields/variables as private
2) provide public get and set methods (through properties) to access and update the value of a private field

sections.name: what-is-a-property
sections.heading: Properties
paragraphs: Private variables can only be accessed within the same class.
Sometimes we need to access private variables from outside the class, and we can do that with properties.
A property is like a combination of a variable and a method, and it has two methods: get and set.

sections.name: example-explained
sections.heading: Example explained
points: The Name property is associated with the private field name.
It is good practice to use the same name for the property and the private field, but with an uppercase first letter for the property.
The get method returns the value of the field.
The set method assigns a value to the field.
The value keyword represents the value being assigned to the property.

sections.name: using-the-property
sections.heading: Access and update private field using property

sections.name: automatic-properties
sections.heading: Automatic Properties (Short Hand)
paragraphs: C# supports automatic properties, where you do not need to define the field explicitly.
You only write get; and set; inside the property.

sections.name: why-encapsulation
sections.heading: Why Encapsulation?
benefits: Better control of class members (reduces mistakes).
Fields can be read-only (only get) or write-only (only set).
Flexible: change one part of the code without affecting other parts.

exercise.question: What is the main purpose of encapsulation in C#?
options: To allow all data to be publicly accessible.
To make sure sensitive data is hidden from unauthorized access.
To speed up the execution of code.
exercise.answer: To make sure sensitive data is hidden from unauthorized access.

sections.name: inheritance-derived-base
sections.heading: Inheritance (Derived and Base Class)
paragraphs: In C#, it is possible to inherit fields and methods from one class to another.
We group inheritance into two categories:
Derived Class (child) - the class that inherits from another class
Base Class (parent) - the class being inherited from
To inherit from a class, use the : symbol.

sections.name: inheritance-example
sections.heading: Example

sections.name: why-use-inheritance
sections.heading: Why And When To Use Inheritance?
points: Useful for code reusability.
Reuse fields and methods of an existing class when you create a new class.

sections.name: sealed-keyword
sections.heading: The sealed Keyword
paragraphs: If you don't want other classes to inherit from a class, use the sealed keyword.
If you try to inherit from a sealed class, C# will generate an error.

exercise.question: Drag and drop the correct access modifier to allow model to be accessed in inherited classes.

sections.name: polymorphism-intro
sections.heading: Polymorphism and Overriding Methods
paragraphs: Polymorphism means "many forms", and it occurs when we have many classes that are related to each other by inheritance.
Inheritance lets us inherit fields and methods from another class.
Polymorphism uses those methods to perform different tasks.
This allows us to perform a single action in different ways.

sections.name: polymorphism-example-without-override
sections.heading: Example (Without virtual/override)

sections.heading: Not The Output I Was Looking For
paragraphs: The output above is not what you expected.
That is because the base class method is used when calling through a base class reference.
To get different outputs, C# allows overriding using virtual and override keywords.

sections.name: polymorphism-example-with-override
sections.heading: Example (With virtual and override)

sections.name: why-use-polymorphism
sections.heading: Why Use Inheritance and Polymorphism?
points: Useful for code reusability.
Reuse fields and methods of an existing class when you create a new class.

sections.name: abstraction-intro
sections.heading: Abstract Classes and Methods
paragraphs: Data abstraction is the process of hiding certain details and showing only essential information to the user.
Abstraction can be achieved with either abstract classes or interfaces.

sections.name: abstract-keyword
sections.heading: The abstract keyword
paragraphs: The abstract keyword is used for classes and methods.
points: Abstract class: a restricted class that cannot be used to create objects. To access it, it must be inherited from another class.
Abstract method: can only be used in an abstract class, and it does not have a body. The body is provided by the derived class.

sections.name: abstract-class-example
sections.heading: Abstract class with abstract and regular methods

sections.name: cannot-create-object
sections.heading: Cannot create an object of an abstract class

sections.name: abstraction-full-example
sections.heading: Example (Abstract class + Inheritance)

sections.name: why-use-abstraction
sections.heading: Why Use Abstract Classes and Methods?
points: To achieve security (hide certain details and only show important details of an object).
Abstraction can also be achieved with Interfaces.

exercise.question: What is the purpose of abstraction in C#?
options: To allow direct access to all class members.
To hide certain details and show only the essential information.
To prevent inheritance in a class.
exercise.answer: To hide certain details and show only the essential information.

sections.name: interface-intro
sections.heading: Interfaces
paragraphs: Another way to achieve abstraction in C#, is with interfaces.
An interface is a completely "abstract class", which can only contain abstract methods and properties (with empty bodies).

sections.name: interface-basic-example
sections.heading: Interface Example

sections.name: interface-naming-tip
sections.heading: Naming Interfaces
paragraphs: It is considered good practice to start with the letter "I" at the beginning of an interface.
By default, members of an interface are abstract and public.
sections.note: Note: Interfaces can contain properties and methods, but not fields.

sections.name: implement-interface
sections.heading: Implement an Interface
paragraphs: To access the interface methods, the interface must be implemented by another class.
To implement an interface, use the : symbol (just like inheritance).
The body of the interface method is provided by the implementing class.
You do not have to use the override keyword when implementing an interface.

sections.name: notes-on-interfaces
sections.heading: Notes on Interfaces
list: Interfaces cannot be used to create objects.
Interface methods do not have a body (the body is provided by the implementing class).
When implementing an interface, you must implement all its methods.
Interfaces can contain properties and methods, but not fields/variables.
Interface members are by default abstract and public.
An interface cannot contain a constructor.

sections.name: why-use-interfaces
sections.heading: Why And When To Use Interfaces?
points: To achieve security - hide certain details and only show the important details of an object.
C# does not support multiple inheritance (a class can only inherit from one base class), but it can implement multiple interfaces.
sections.note: To implement multiple interfaces, separate them with a comma.

exercise.question: What is an interface in C#?
options: A class that contains both abstract and concrete methods.
A completely abstract class that can only contain abstract methods and properties.
A class that cannot be inherited.
A class that must have a constructor.
exercise.answer: A completely abstract class that can only contain abstract methods and properties.

sections.name: enum-intro
sections.heading: C# Enums
paragraphs: An enum is a special "class" that represents a group of constants (unchangeable/read-only variables).
To create an enum, use the enum keyword (instead of class or interface), and separate the enum items with a comma.

sections.name: enum-create
sections.heading: Create an Enum

sections.name: enum-access
sections.heading: Access Enum Items
paragraphs: You can access enum items with the dot syntax:
sections.example:
Level myVar = Level.Medium;
Console.WriteLine(myVar);

sections.name: enum-meaning
sections.heading: Meaning
paragraphs: Enum is short for "enumerations", which means "specifically listed".

sections.name: enum-inside-class
sections.heading: Enum inside a Class

sections.name: enum-values-default
sections.heading: Enum Values (Default)
paragraphs: By default, the first item of an enum has the value 0. The second has the value 1, and so on.
To get the integer value from an item, you must explicitly convert the item to an int.

sections.name: enum-values-custom
sections.heading: Assign Your Own Enum Values
paragraphs: You can also assign your own enum values, and the next items will update their numbers accordingly:

sections.name: enum-switch
sections.heading: Enum in a Switch Statement
paragraphs: Enums are often used in switch statements to check for corresponding values:

sections.name: enum-why-use
sections.heading: Why And When To Use Enums?
paragraphs: Use enums when you have values that you know aren't going to change, like month days, days, colors, deck of cards, etc.

exercise.question: What is an enum in C#?
options: A variable that can store multiple values.
A special 'class' that represents a group of constants.
A method that returns multiple values.
A data type that allows runtime changes.
exercise.answer: A special 'class' that represents a group of constants.

sections.name: files-intro
sections.heading: Working With Files
paragraphs: The File class from the System.IO namespace, allows us to work with files.

sections.name: files-namespace
sections.heading: System.IO Namespace
paragraphs: You must include the System.IO namespace to work with files.
sections.example:
using System.IO;  // include the System.IO namespace

File.SomeFileMethod();  // use the File class with methods

sections.name: files-methods
sections.heading: Common File Methods
paragraphs: The File class has many useful methods for creating and getting information about files.

table.description: Appends text at the end of an existing file
Reads the contents of a file
Replaces the contents of a file with the contents of another file
Creates a new file and writes the contents to it. If the file already exists, it will be overwritten.

sections.note: For a full list of File methods, go to Microsoft .NET File Class Reference.

sections.name: files-write-read
sections.heading: Write To a File and Read It
paragraphs: In this example, we use WriteAllText() to create a file and write content to it.
Then we use ReadAllText() to read the contents of the file.
sections.example:
using System.IO;  // include the System.IO namespace

string writeText = "Hello World!";  // Create a text string
File.WriteAllText("filename.txt", writeText);  // Create a file and write the content of writeText to it

string readText = File.ReadAllText("filename.txt");  // Read the contents of the file
Console.WriteLine(readText);  // Output the content

sections.name: exceptions-intro
sections.heading: C# Exceptions
paragraphs: When executing C# code, different errors can occur: coding errors made by the programmer, errors due to wrong input, or other unforeseeable things.
When an error occurs, C# will normally stop and generate an error message. The technical term for this is: C# will throw an exception (throw an error).

sections.name: try-catch-intro
sections.heading: C# try and catch
paragraphs: The try statement allows you to define a block of code to be tested for errors while it is being executed.
The catch statement allows you to define a block of code to be executed, if an error occurs in the try block.
The try and catch keywords come in pairs:

sections.name: try-catch-syntax
sections.heading: Syntax

sections.name: exception-example-error
sections.heading: Example (Error Case)
paragraphs: Consider the following example, where we create an array of three integers.
This will generate an error, because myNumbers[10] does not exist.
sections.example:
int[] myNumbers = {1, 2, 3};
Console.WriteLine(myNumbers[10]); // error!

sections.name: exception-message
sections.heading: Exception Message
paragraphs: The error message will be something like this:
sections.output: System.IndexOutOfRangeException: 'Index was outside the bounds of the array.'

sections.name: try-catch-handle
sections.heading: Handle Exception Using try...catch
paragraphs: If an error occurs, we can use try...catch to catch the error and execute some code to handle it.
In this example, we use the variable inside the catch block (e) together with the built-in Message property, which outputs a message that describes the exception:

sections.name: try-catch-output
sections.heading: Output
sections.output: Index was outside the bounds of the array.

sections.name: custom-error-message
sections.heading: Custom Error Message
paragraphs: You can also output your own error message:

sections.name: finally-block
sections.heading: Finally
paragraphs: The finally statement lets you execute code, after try...catch, regardless of the result:
sections.output:
Something went wrong.
The 'try catch' is finished.

sections.name: throw-keyword
sections.heading: The throw keyword
paragraphs: The throw statement allows you to create a custom error.
The throw statement is used together with an exception class.
There are many exception classes available in C#: ArithmeticException, FileNotFoundException, IndexOutOfRangeException, TimeOutException, etc:

sections.name: throw-example
sections.heading: Example (throw)
sections.output: System.ArithmeticException: 'Access denied - You must be at least 18 years old.'

sections.name: throw-success
sections.heading: Example (No Exception)
paragraphs: If age was 20, you would not get an exception:
sections.example: checkAge(20);
sections.output: Access granted - You are old enough!

exercise.question: What will happen if an exception occurs inside a try block and there is no catch block?
options: The program will continue executing the next statement.
The program will handle the error automatically.
The program will terminate with an error message.
The program will ignore the error.
exercise.answer: The program will terminate with an error message.
